Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Form and Function of Bacterial Amyloid Fibers

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
The propensity for bacteria to associate with surfaces in nearly all ecosystems far exceeds the tendency to persist in suspension, living freely in a planktonic state. Bacteria secrete proteins, polysaccharides, and other components to assemble a spider-web like matrix that surrounds cells to promote the formation of protective communities termed biofilms. The protective physical matrix enables bacteria to colonize and even thrive in an astonishing range of environments, in niches ranging from the harsh acidic microbial mats in Yellowstone to ship hulls and industrial oil pipelines. Improved biofilm models are crucial to understanding how they function. Across biology, chemistry, and materials research, measuring parameters of chemical, physical, and mechanical properties is key to understanding how complex assemblies function. In this project, experiments are designed to achieve breakthrough discoveries needed to transform biofilm descriptors from vague terms like "glue" and "slime" to scientific and quantitative descriptions based on chemical composition and molecular architecture by using high resolution techniques. The self-assembly of these macromolecular architectures by bacteria also inspire us to use or build such mechanically robust molecular frameworks for new functions.

In this project, the PI will engage in broad dissemination of scientific research and educational outreach activities. She will mentor undergraduate and graduate students, including many from groups under-represented in STEM; design coursework changes to introduce more quantitative concepts into biochemistry courses; and lead comprehensive outreach activities, engaging students, teachers, and the general public. Major specific activities include: (i) developing a biochemical biofilm laboratory module for the high-school science curriculum with assistance from a high-school teacher who joins the PI's laboratory each summer, (ii) integrating exploratory-based lab modules in undergraduate laboratory courses to encourage true engagement and the hands-on "a-ha" moments that enhance learning; (iii) assisting in the mentoring of incoming first-generation and under-represented undergraduate students in preparation for university coursework in STEM; and (iv) sharing engineering protocols for a custom-built active-control feedback system to stabilize NMR pulse power levels over long acquisition times, enhancing the stability of NMR experiments and also of general value in spectrometer monitoring. Overall, the commitment to educational and scientific outreach in this project integrates research with teaching, mentoring, and K-12 outreach activities to inspire and empower others to impact and improve the society.

In this project, amyloid fibers produced by E. coli, known as curli, will be studied. Curli mediate bacterial adhesion and contribute to biofilm formation. This project will provide unprecedented detail into the atomic structure and function of native curli fibers and will map their interactions with amyloid dyes and their cognate biofilm polysaccharide partners by integrating unique solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) strategies to measure atomic-level distances together with super-resolution microscopy to examine the larger-scale spatial arrangement of curli and other components in the biofilm. This project is jointly funded by Molecular Biophysics and Cellular Dynamics and Function Clusters in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Bacteria secrete and surround themselves with molecular polymers as building materials to enmesh and protect resident bacteria in communities termed biofilms. Biofilms enhance bacterial survival, enabling them to thrive in astonishing environments, ranging from within the human host to the acidic microbial mats in Yellowstone and industrial oil pipelines. Biofilms play crucial ecological roles and humans harness biofilm metabolism to clean wastewater and produce various fermented food products. Unfortunately, many biofilms are harmful. Biofilm-contaminated food and food-processing equipment cause disease outbreaks. Biofilms are also associated with other serious infections. We have been inspired by the need to define how bacteria assemble these complex protective materials that surround their communities. Discoveries could lead to better ways to inhibit and control biofilm formation. Discoveries could also reveal the fundamental molecular basis for how nature produces such remarkable physical materials that could inspire the generation of new materials for society. Silk and cellulose are remarkable examples of nature's materials with unique properties used throughout the world.

Decoding the blueprints of extracellular matrix architectures surrounding bacteria in biofilms poses a challenge to analysis by conventional methods due to the insolubility and heterogenous nature of the biofilm matrix and the diverse biopolymers that can contribute to matrix assembly. We addressed this challenge and introduced unique and unconventional tools to elucidate composition, structure and function in these complex and insoluble assemblies. We introduced state-of-the-art macromolecular and whole-cell solid-state NMR strategies together with interfacial rheology, biochemistry, chemical genetics and microscopy to examine insoluble extracellular matrices and whole biofilms. We defined the composition of insoluble extracellular matrix materials of bacteria including E. coli and V. cholerae and the fungus A. fumigatus, and developed methods for matrix isolation and improved ultrastructural analysis by electron microscopy.

Furthermore, our unique approach served as an invaluable discovery tool. Cellulose is the most abundant biopolymer on Earth. We discovered the production of an unprecedented chemically modified form of cellulose - phosphoethanolamine (pEtN) cellulose. Decades of study on laboratory strains and pathogenic E. coli and Salmonella biofilms had assumed these organisms were producing unmodified cellulose based on conventional isolation and detection protocols. Our work presented the first definitve evidence of a chemically modified cellulose produced in nature. We identified the genetic and molecular basis for installation of the modification. The identification of the gene-directed biosynthetic machinery inspires the search for others and inspires the generation of engineered systems to produce alternately modified and functionalized cellulosic materials. We also introduced a new approach using cutting-edge instrumentation and established a molecular role for pEtN cellulose in facilitating adhesion of E. coli to mammalian cells. Our results suggested a model wherein pEtN cellulose acts as a "glue" to keep curli amyloid fibers associated at the bacterial cell surface to permit strong attachment to mammalian cells. Our collective work and perspectives were reported in 20 published research articles, 1 chemical education article, 4 review articles, and 2 patents.

Broader Impacts. Throughout this award, new approaches were introduced that have widespread applicability to the examination of complex assemblies throughout biology and materials chemistry. The project also involved active training and mentoring and public outreach to impact other people and society beyond the intellectual merits of the project. This included undergraduate and graduate students underrepresented in STEM. Each summer, a high school teacher participated in research in the laboratory to help excite them about research, which in turn inspired them to convey their experiences to their students. The research group also carried out extensive hands-on workshops at high schools throughout the bay area. The PI also delivered seminars and visited with students at primarily undergraduate institutions and participated in broad speaking engagements, including sharing a seminar entitled "Entanglements of Art and Science."

Finally, in major curriculum development, we took the opportunity to introduce exploratory and open-ended experimental options in a Biochemistry Laboratory course typically taken by junior and senior chemistry majors. We designed a 3-week module entitled "Explorations at the Interface of Microbiology and Biochemistry" as a CURE, wherein CURE refers to a Course-based Undergraduate Research Experience. The module incorporated the five components of a CURE course: broadly relevant or important work, use of scientific processes, collaboration, discovery, and iteration. The broad-reaching phenomenon of bacterial biofilm formation served as the heart of the scientific area. Unlike laboratory classes where students are provided a cookbook-like manual, this module required students to develop experimental plans. This CURE was intended to elevate interest among junior and senior students, to enhance their research experiences, and infuse them with a sense of real discovery that comes from independent research as they launch into careers in science and other areas. The module does not require sophisticated equipment or resources and can be readily implemented at other schools and programs.
